page.title: 06LOCAL HISTORY-ASHTON KEYNES
page.content: To the east of The Church is one of the {four crosses}which can be seen in the village. The others are at the end of Church Walk; by the White Hart Inn and by one of the shops. No-one knows why the crosses were erected. They may have been "preaching crosses" or some past indication of Ashton Keynes' importance as a crossing point of the Thames on the Marlborough to Cirencester road. Many of the names of houses in the village tell of former uses. You can find 'forges' and 'mill', and two former chapels which are now houses. Another feature to look for is the 'tilestones' of limestone, marking boundries of some of the gardens. They stand about sixty centimetres high.
